head.supplied: Question one: Whether the human mind is an image of the uncreated Trinity just as the vestige of the same Trinity is found in others things made for man

div.p: Concerning the third distinction, I ask whether the human mind is an image of the uncreated Trinity just as the vestige of the same Trinity is found in others things made for man.

It seems that not because according to
Augustine in the Common sermon about on martyr
if man had preserved within himself the good that God created in him, that is his image, he would always praise God not only with our words but also with our life
Auctor incertus (forte Augustinus, Sermo CCCXV (PL 39:2349)).
etc. Therefore from the opposite: Man does not praise in this way,
therefore he does not preserve this good in himself, namely the image of God, and nevertheless he preserves his mind. Therefore the human mind is not the image of God.

Again,
14 On the Trinity, c. 7, de parvis
Augustinus, De Trinitate, Bk. XIV, c. 4, n. 6 (PL 42:??? CCSL ???).
he says according to
the Psalm
indeed man passes in an image
sed etc.
Psalmus 38:7
because this image has been made so deformed and obscure, there it is practically nothing. But this human mind remains whole according to its own substance, therefor according to its own substance it is not an image of the Trinity.

Again, then the mind would be more greatly the image of God than man because
whatever is the cause, is also greater
Aristoteles An. Posterior I, c. 2, n. 15 (27a29)
each one account of that and that is greater. The consequent is false because man is more similar to God than the mind, and is expressed by Him, therefore he is more His image. This consequence is clear through the definition of image which is posted by
Augustine, On the 83 questions, question 74 , where he says that
the image is an expressed
likeness of that of which it is an image
Augustinus,
De diversis quaestionibus octoginta , q. 74 (CCSL ???; PL 40:86):
. The assumed is proved because man is a more noble being than the mind of man, therefore is of a greater likeness to God. The consequence is clear through
Anselm, Monologion in chapters 31 and 66 , where he says:
among created things whatever is more similar to God, that is necessarily of a better nature
Anselm, Monologion, c. 66 (Schmitt I:77):
. The assumed is proved because
I Ethics, chapter 8 near the end, the Philosopher says
that
happiness plus the smallest about of good things is more choice worthy than happiness itself
Aristotle, Ethics, Bk. I, c. 7 (1097b21).
. And he adds that a greater good is always more choice worthy. Therefore, by an equal reasons, the human mind combined with any good is better than the mind alone. Therefore, what is composed from this mind and body, namely man, is more noble than the mind alone.

Again, if the human mind is the image of the uncreated Trinity, therefore this is either by reason of its substance (which is not the case because the mind does not represent a distinction of persons), or by reasons of the acts which it causes and receives (and this is not the case because these acts are not consubstantial). And the same thing as if it were real is argued under another form thus: if this were the case, then the perfect cognition of that image would be able to lead to, or at least assist in, knowing that Trinity is in God. The consequent is false because its cognition does not lead more greatly to true cognition of the uncreated Trinity than anything else. Proof, for either there is in the soul a real distinction of powers or this does not seem to be the case. For if this were the case, then there are diverse things and consequently they are either parts of the mind or accidents in it, and thus this cognition would force us to think that the persons are either parts of God or accidents in him, and thus they are not God. But if not, then it would force us to think that the persons are not really distinguished.

Again, specifically that the mind is not the image by reason of its own acts because
in 14 De Trinitate, chapter 6 de parvis, Augustine says
that,
the image of the creator is immortally introduced to the rational or intellectual mind of man
Augustinus, De Trinitate, Bk. XIV, c. 3, n. 6 (CCSL 50A:428; PL 42:1040)
, but the acts have not been so immortally attached, therefore. And again
in the same book, Augustine claims , that
this image should not apply to transitory things
Augustinus, De Trinitate, Bk. XIV, c. 2, n. 4 (CCSL 50A:425; PL 42: 1038)
. But acts are transitory things, therefore.

On the contrary:
Genesis I,
Let us make man in our own image
Genesis 1:26
etc., and
Augustine, Literal commentary on Genesis, c. 23 de parvis
Augustinus, De Genesi ad litteram, Bk. VI, c. 28, n. 39 (CCSL ???; PL 34:356-357)
, he says that man is made in the image of God, according to the mind, according to the
Apostole :
be renewed by the spirit of your mind
Paulus, Ad Ephesios 4:23.
. And in c. 26 he concludes that
in the mind man is made according to the image of God
Augustinus, De Genesi ad litteram, Bk. VI, c. 12, n. 22 (CCSL ???; PL 34: ???):
, etc. Of the same opinion is the
Master, in the text, in book 2, in distinction 16
Petrus Lombardus, Sententiae, Bk II, d. 16, c. 3 (Quarachi, 1:408):
.

To the same is
Augustine XII De Trinitate, c. 17 de parvis ,
no one, he says,
doubts that is not according to the body nor according to some other part, but according to the rational mind, where there is able to be a recognition of God, that man is made according to the image of the one who created him.
Augustine, De Trinitate, Bk. XII, c. 7, n. 12 (PL 42:1004--1005)
.

Again, this authority also rightly holds the contrary of the first and the second. For to the first part
Augustine XIV De Trinitate, c. 14 de parvis , say that
the mind in itself should be considered before it is participant of God and in this its image should be received. For we have said that it (the mind), even if destroyed and deformed through the removal of its participation in God, nevertheless remains the image of God. Indeed by itself it is an image of God, in which lies its capacity to also be a participant of it.
Augustinus, De Trinitate, Bk. XIV, c. 8, n. 11 (CCSL ????; PL 42:1044)

In the fifth place, there are to this part many other authorities both with respect to the image and with respect to the trace which are posited by the
Master, in the text of the present distinction
Petrus Lombardus, Sententiae, Bk. I, d. 3, c. 1--3 (Quarachi, 1:70--76).
, and also
some other authorities in book 2, distinction 16
Petrus Lombardus, Sententiae, Bk II, d. 16, c. 1-4 (Quarachi, 1:406--409).
.

In this question the conclusion is certain that it is so. But it should be seen in the first place why there is in creatures a trace of the Trinity or the image of the Trinity in man. And in the second place, some doubts will be introduced against what has been said.

head.supplied: Conditions common to the trace and image

div.p:
Regarding the first, it should be known that there are some conditions common both to the trace and to the image, and some properly to former or to the latter. One of the common conditions is that both the trace and the image lead to a cognition or knowledge of that of which it is an image or trace as if causative of the knowledge of that of which it is an image or trace.
by mediating its knowledge. But it does not lead into the first distinct and proper knowledge of that of which it is an image or trace because from what has been determined elsewhere it is clear that incomplex knowledge of one thing does not lead into distinct and proper and simple incomplex first knowledge of another thing, but rather it does only through this mode by which one thing as a mediating incomplex knowledge is able to be the partial cause of the remembrance of another habitually known, such that the habitual knowledge necessarily concurs as a partial cause.

This is declared by
Ockham through experience and does so well
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 9 (OTh II:544s.)
. For having posited that
someone does not have prior cognition of Hercules, if he should see a statue of Hercules he will not thing more of Hercules than of Socrates. But if earlier he had seen Hercules and retained the habitual knowledge of Hercules
(or he learned about some of the proper imitated properties in its image through hearing)
and afterwards he sees that the statue is similar to it in its exterior accidents, by virtue of his vision
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 9 (OTh II:545)
he will be able to recall Hercules, even having posited that he never before had seen this statue.

Also similar to this is the fact that sometimes seeing a tree or a stone from far off, and at first we think about a person and judge that a person is there, which certainly would not happen unless there were a prepossessed habitual knowledge of a person, since the tree or stone does not contain virtually and prime knowledge of a person, and in the same way about similar things.

And just as it is about the image of Hercules with respect to remembering Hercules,
so it is about the trace, because if someone sees a trace of cow, it will call to mind a cow which has been habitually seen; but if one never had such knowledge, it would call to mind a cow no more than a donkey.
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 9 (OTh II:545):

Also through this mode
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 9 (OTh II:545s)
, two similar things would both be able to lead into recalling knowledge of themselves, for whoever had habitual knowledge of either. And similarly one maximally similar thing after having been seen would be able to lead to similar recalling knowledge of something known prior on account of the likeness of one thing to another.
Further other conditions could be assigned where they fit, but they are less serious, therefore I pass over them.

head.supplied: The opinion of Ockham on the differences between trace and image

div.p:
Also
the trace and the image differ because it belongs to the ratio of the trace to be caused by that thing in whose likeness is the trace.
in some mode,
just as it is clear inductively
from the trace of a cow, from the trace of combustion, and from similar things. And here is the case that the trace
is called something left behind by another. But the ratio of the image is not caused by that of which it is an image, for it suffices that the image of Hercules is caused by something other than Hercules
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 9 (OTh II:547).
.

Nevertheless note that most strictly or most properly speaking about the image, and not in the common way as was the case before, it is proper to the ratio of the image that it is an extracted or begotten likeness from that of which it is an image, just as is said by
Augustine ,
in 83 questions , question 74 , just as he exemplified there:
as in a mirror he says,
it is the image of a man because it is extracted from him . In is similar in the case of parents children, for likewise
from a parent the likeness of a child is extracted, such that it is rightly called an image.
Augustinus,
De 83 quaestionibus , q. 74 (PL 40:86).
. And nevertheless the image is properly understood in the sense that I have adopted from the witness of the
Master, in book 2, distinction 16, chapter 2
where he says on behalf of the
authority of Bede
Bedae, In Genesim, I, 26 (PL 91:29b; CCL 188A:25).
speaking about the fact that the Trinity
is improperly called an image
the cause of which is,
because the image
he says,
is relatively said with respect to another which the image carries a likeness and to which it is made in order to represent, just as the image of Ceasar, which carried a likeness of him and represented him in some mode
Petrus Lombardus, Sententiae, Bk. II, d. 16, c. 3 (Quarachi I:407)
.

From this difference another follows: that the trace leads or is able to lead not only into complex recalling knowledge of that of which is habitually known, but also into other complex contingent things and even like assent to these things, into similar things of which the image is not sufficiently able to lead. For example, the trace of a cow is not able to cause the remembrance of a cow habitually known, but leads commonly into conforming belief to the following contingent proposition a cow has travelled here, but the image of Peter does not lead to the following, Peter has travelled here and other propositions of this type. However, trace and image are understood in various senses, just as is clear in the case of
Ockham
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 9-10 (OTh II:544--9, 553)
.

But how any creature is able to be called in some mode the trace of the Trinity, such that, namely, somethings in that creature, like unity, species, and order, are able in some mode to lead into incomplex recalling knowledge of those things that belong to the divine persons, and even into complex contingent knowledge, is sufficiently well taught by
Ockham, in the question on the trace, article two
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 9 (OTh II:548, l.8--549, l.2).
. And again in the same place, in what things in the creature the trace consists
because sometimes it is in really distinct things, and sometimes in non-really-distinct things.

And similarly in the
question on the image, in the second article
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 10 (OTh II:557--9)
.
In the first of which, in the proper opinion
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 10 (OTh II:555--7)
, he teaches how in a rational creature the image is said to be more present than in any other creature. And
in the second place
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 10 (OTh II:557--9)
he consequently teaches how
the imperfect image of God both radically and originally consists in this soul according to the substance of the soul, but the full perfection of the image consists in the substance of the soul and two produced acts
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 10 (OTh II:557).
, and with respect to each act the soul is productive; . but for the act of willing to occur, there is a mediating act of understanding, which with the substance of the soul and the object, co-produces the act of willing, and consequently the soul expresses with these acts the order and origin that exists between the persons.

But that the act of willing is effectively from the act of understanding
Guillelmus de Ockham, Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 10 (OTh II:559)
, he also proves well. And I concede the conclusion and I hold this in
distinction 1
Wodeham, Ordinatio, I, d. 1, XXX
because
every absolute thing necessarily presupposed by another has with respect to that the ratio of the cause in some genus of cause. But so it is about the act of understanding with respect to the act of willing, therefore
Guillelmus de Ockham Scriptum in Sent., Bk. I, d. 3, q. 10 (OTh II:559).
. Also the major is conceded by
Scotus, in distinction 3 of book 1
Iohannes Duns Scotus, Ordinatio, Bk. I, d. 3, pars 3, q. 4, n. 589 (Vatican 3:348)
, and he uses this because, according to him,
every effect of something sufficiently depends on its essential causes
Iohannes Duns Scotus, Ordinatio, I, d. 3, pars 3, q. 2, n. 414 (Vatican 3:251)
, therefore, etc.

Against this there is the first doubt about that in which the ratio of the image is said to consist because it does not seem that that the ratio of the image consists in the substance of the soul in some mode, even imperfectly, because the image necessarily requires some distinction. But in the substance of the soul there is no distinction, therefore it does not have the ratio of the image in any mode.

Again, nor does it seem to be in the substance of the soul and the two acts because between the parts of the image there ought be consubstantiality. But between the substance of the soul and its acts there is no consubstantiality, therefore, etc.

Again, according to
Augustine, XIV De Trinitate, c. 3 de magnis :
the image of God in the rational creature is immortal
Augustinus, De Trinitate, Bk. XIV, c. 3, n. 6 (CCSL 50A:428; PL 42:1040).
. But these second acts
are not immortal nor incorporeal, therefore.

Again, according to this it would be possible to find in the mind an image with respect to any intelligible or loveable object, the opposite of which is maintained by
Augustine, XII De Trinitate, c. 4 de magnis :
in him alone, he says,
because to the contemplation of eternal things pertains, not only the Trinity, but also the image of God. But in this which has been derived in the action of temporal things, even if a trinity were possible, nevertheless an image of God would not be able to be found
Augustinus, De Trinitate, XII, c. 4, n. 4 (CCSL 50:358; PL 42:1000)
. And
XIV De Trinitate, c. 23 de parvis , he says that
therefore the trinity of the mind is not an image of God because the mind remembers itself and understand and loves itself, but because it is able to remember and understand and love him by whom it was made
Augustinus, De Trinitate, XIV, c. 12, n. 15 (CCSL 50A:442-443; PL 42:1048)
.

In the fifth place, because by the same argument there would be in the sensitive part an image of the Trinity, for even there the substance of the soul with an object begins the process of sensitive cognition and with cognition begins the sensitive act of apprehending. Therefore here there is equally origination and the order in likeness to the Trinity just as in the intellect, granted that the ratio of the image should be understood in this way. The consequent is not conceded, therefore etc.

head.supplied: Response to the arguments of the first doubt

div.p:
To the first it is true that in order to save the ratio of the image in the rational mind, some posit a certain distinction or non-identity between the substance of the soul and the intellect and will, just as
Scotus in II, distinction 16
Iohannes Duns Scotus, Ordinatio, Bk. II, d. 16, q. 1, n. 17-19 (Wadding, VI, 772)
. But according to the same author in the same place, no argument is sufficiently able to prove that such a distinction exists,
as I have shown above, in the last question of the first distinction
Wodeham, I, d. 1, q. ?? . Nor does this seem to me necessary in order to save the image because, if several powers were really the same, then this would not preserve some sort of origination between these powers, etc.

But because I do not hold that there is such a distinction between powers of the soul, I say with the Subtle Doctor and the
Master, in the text, in this distinction 3 , that a likeness of the image to the prototype is not able to be found in us because
according to the Master
Petrus Lombardus, Sententiae, Bk. I, d. 3, c. 3 (Quarachi, 1:74-75)
there is more dislikeness than likeness, and therefore I say that there are not three things in our mind that our really distinct, among which there is a similar ratio of the origin, of two things from one thing, and of one thing from two, with consubstantiality, that is, with an essential identity of three really distinct things. It is therefore necessary that the ratio of the image is understood either with respect to origination and distinction or with respect to consubstantiality. And above all this is not unsuitable for that in which the ratio of the image (of which the substance of the soul is) consists only principally or virtually.

To the second, I say that the image is deficient in consubstantiality in comparison to the Trinity of Persons, between which there is consubstantiality. It is nevertheless true that it is possible that there are some signs expressive of those distinct parts which are truly affirmed about the same substance, and perhaps this is the consubstantiality which the authors intend to hold there, for the same substance is memory, intelligence, and will. For thus
according to Augustine
and asserted in the text of
distinction 3, I
Petrus Lombardus, Sententiae, Bk. I, d. 3, c. 2, n.7 (Quaracchi, 1:73-74)
,
they are said relatively to one another
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IX, c. 5, n. 8 (CCSL 50: 301; PL 42:965).
which would not able to be unless they signified distinct things which are the substance of the soul.

To the third, I say that some things, through which we express distinct parts of the image, are never truly removed from the rational soul. Whence the following is in itself true and necessary:
if the soul is formed, then there is memory, intelligence, and will, at least if the soul exists. And Augustine, when he says the image is immortal, does not intend anything other than that the soul necessarily and immmortally, while remaining itself, is like that which is meant when it is said to be memory, intelligence, and will.

To the fourth,
Scotus
Iohannes Duns Scotus, Ordinatio, Bk. I, d. 3, pars 3, q. 4, n. 590 (Vatican, 3:349)
responds well with respect to God as an object, the ultimate and most perfect ratio of the image is held in the mind because then these three things are not only an expressive likeness of the uncreated Trinity, from which there are three such things relating to themselves in this way, but more than this because every act is truly a likeness of the object of which it is and some expressed image of it, though equivocal. Therefore when these acts are elicited with respect to God as object, then the image and the conformity to the uncreated Trinity is had more perfectly, most especially when the objective Trinity is found in the object corresponding in some mode to the subjective trinity in the mind which does not happen in other objects.

From the same solution
vide supra (Cross Reference to above paragraph)
it is clear with respect to the fifth that the most perfect ratio of the image possible to be had in a creature with respect to the Trinity is not in the soul and its sensitive acts because these acts are not able to have God as their object. Nevertheless it seems to me that in the sensitive human, which is the same as the its intellective human, the image of the Trinity is able to be posited in the substance and sensitive acts ordered in the manner mentioned above, (although a more imperfect image than with respect to a purely intelligible object) because the sensitive and appetitive human acts are simple and nonextended, just as intellective and volitional acts. (And this different from the way it is in a brute, where such acts are extended forms.) And therefore, though more imperfect,
there is a likeness to the most simple uncreated Trinity.
Second principal doubt is whether second part of the uncreated image, namely the actual intellection, is begotten from the first, namely from the memory.

head.supplied: Principal arguments for the second doubt

div.p:
And it seems that not, in the first place, because then what would be called memory is indeed the pure substance of the soul, and this does not suffice without an object, or species, or a habit initiating an act, for if it did then it would always be understanding, just as the
Philosopher argues in book II De anima , that
the sense would always be sensing
Aristoteles, De anima II, c. 5 (XXX)
, if it would by itself alone actualize sensations, and not the intellect with species or habit
because actual intellection is not distinguished from habit or species just as it is not produced by them. The assumed is clear because actual sensation is a species in the sense, therefore similarly in the intellect. The antecedent is clear through the
Philosopher
Aristoteles, De anima III, c.2, 425b12ff
and the
Commentator II De anima comment 136,
Averroes, Comm. de anima, II, 136 (Crawford pp.337f)
where they say and prove that the sensible action and the sense as it is in act are the same thing. As the
Commentator , explains
sensible action outside the soul in moving the sense, and the action of sensing, which is in the one sensing, namely the quality by which the one sensing is qualified, is the same action
Averroes, In Aristot. De anima, II, 138 (Crawford, 340-341)
. This the
Commentator also in the two following comments
exemplifies with respect to hearing:
just as he says,
the action of hearing, that is to hear, and the action of having sounded, that is to sound, are the same thing
.

Similarly, that actual intellection is not distinguished from habit is seen from the fact that this would be generated from acts, and then there would immediately be a habit and a most perfect act able to be received in this potency, since the first act would be causative of the habit. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because the first act causes some degree of habit, and the intellect with this grade will cause more of the act than it had been able to before it had nothing from the habit. Therefore the act would be intensified, and the more intense the act, the more of the habit it will cause, and thus circularly without end, until the intellect has something of the species both of this and of that, to the degree that it is able to reach. But this is false. Therefore also this from which it follows is false, namely that the act is distinguished from the habit. Therefore intellection is not, like an offspring, proceeding from the memory, like a parent.

To this doubt, I say at the present that indeed actual intellection is distinguished, like an offspring, from memory (that is from an intellect existing in a first act sufficient with respect to begetting an intellection) either through the presence of an object with respect to a first act naturally causable in it with respect to such an object, or through a species or habit afterwards in the absence of the object with respect to abstractive cognition begetting with respect to such an absent object. Whence this is true regarding the causing of first intellective act, (namely with respect to such an natural object). This is held by
Augustine, IX De Trinitate, 30 de parvis :
the knowledge is brought forth from each, namely from the one knowing and from the thing known
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IX, c. 12, n. 18 (CCSL 50:309; PL 42:970)
, and
said nearby in XV De Trinitate, c. 24 de parvis , he says,
when we speak what we know, the word is born from knowledge we have with memory, which is entirely of the same kind -- supply of the object -- as the knowledge from which it born
Augustinus, De Trinitate XV, c. 10, n. 19 (CCSL 50A:486; PL 42:1071)
. For it immediately follows, it is the case that the expression
of the same kind
refers to the object and does not note the object of cognition,
for, he says, the knowledge formed from that thing which we know is the word which we speak in our heart

Again, in chapter 28, he says that
the word is begotten from the knowledge which remains in the soul
Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, c. 11, n. 20 (CCSL 50A:488; PL 42:1072),
and
similarly in chapter 36 Forte Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, c. 14, n. 24 (CCSL 50A:497; PL 42:1077)
. From these and many other similar authorities it is sufficiently clear that Blessed Augustine agrees that actual intellection is really distinguished from the species or habitual knowledge from which, according to him, it is begotten, as if an offspring from a parent, but in this case from the mind, just as the word is also an offspring of the one speaking.

Nevertheless against his and my opinion, it is able to be argued through the arguments of those who hold that actual cognition is able, while remaining subjectively in the mind, to cease to be intellection, such that in this case the quality will remain, not existing as an intellection, but as a species or habit. Therefore this same thing which is the species or habit when the soul is not in the act of thinking becomes actual thinking when the soul begins to think. Therefore a species or habit distinct from such actual thinking is needlessly posited, and as a consequence it would be needless to posit a real part of the second part of the image coming from the species or habit of the intellect, which naturally presupposes it in the same thing. The assumed is proved in the first place because otherwise if someone were understanding, then they would have at the same time distinct likenesses with respect to the same thing, which seems superfluous. The consequence is clear because likewise according to
Augustine, where he seems to follow this distinction of act from habit or species in 29 De Trinitate, c. 15 and in many other places ,
actual thinking is the greatest likeness to the species from which it is begotten
Augustinus, De Trinitate XV, 12, 22
.

Again, sometimes through the same act the word and another thing in the word is known, and at other times this thing is not known, but other times that thing is not known but rather something else or nothing else This is not the case unless it is granted that the quality, which is the intellection, is able to remain while not being intellection since by what reason would it be able to remain and at the same time not be an intellection of that of which it was an intellection. The same argument applies for everything else.

Further, when I love all good people with one virtuous act, if one of them becomes bad without my knowing, then I cease to love that person with the love with which I loved all such good people inasmuch as they were good, and nevertheless the act does not cease, therefore by this reason the same is true for the intellect.

Further, nothing is loved unless it is known, but a thought is able to be destroyed by God without the destruction of the quality, which is love, therefore this love will then remain, and nevertheless there will not be love. By this reason the same is true for the intellect.

Further, let the love by which Socrates loves himself be put in Plato, then Plato will experience loving himself, therefore then something will be loved through this love which was not loved earlier and will not be loved through the same love that was earlier. The assumption is proved because, if Socrates wishes that he loves an angel, and this volition is put in Plato, then through this wish Plato will wish that he himself loves an angel, therefore similarly in the proposed. And the last assumption is proved because through putting the intellection, by which Socrates experiences himself to understand an angel, in Plato, Plato will experience himself to an understand an angel, therefore similarly also through volition.

Further, the love for Socrates and the hate for Plato are naturally compatible in the will of Socrates, therefore since the hatred for/of Socrates and the hatred for Plato are qualities of the same species, if one is able to exist in some subject together with any form then also the other, but the hate for Plato exists in the will of Socrates together with a love terminated in Socrates, then in the same intellect with a volition terminated in Socrates the hatred of Socrates is able to exist.
However, the hatred for Socrates is not able to exists with the love for Socrates, therefore the hate for Socrates is able to be in the will of Socrates when it will not be the hatred of Socrates.
And by the same reason, this is able to occur for cognition, just as for volition, therefore.

Further, some vision is able to be in the sense of sight while not being a vision, therefore similarly in the intellect regarding intellection. The antecedent is proved because some intellectual part of a one foot long white thing seen from just short of the maximum, , namely the point at which it would not be visible from this distance all things being equal. But if it were present in itself, then it would be seen as a completely white existent thing, and nevertheless, if it were present over there , then it would cease to be seen without this quality ceasing to be, which is now present, therefore the vision, etc.

That this now seems to be true is clear because, if the entire whiteness of surface that faces the eye is seen, then some part of it with respect to the same surface is seen. Nevertheless because every such part contributes to the vision of the whole and adds to the fact that the whole is able to be seen from a distance more remote than the distance that what is left of the whole after this part has been removed would be able to be seen. If all things are equal, then because what is composed from two whitenesses maximally non-visible appears from some distance to have a part outside part in this distance, therefore the middle part of it is seen from such a distance, and by the same reason, the middle of the middle is seen, so on without end. But because this would not be seen, no other whiteness has been seen, and nevertheless the previously possessed quality is conserved with respect to it.
It is argued because sensitive delight is able to be so small and diminished that through it such an appetite is not able to be perceptible delighted, therefore similarly regarding the sensitive vision. The consequence is clear because, just as through a lesser sensitive delight such an appetite is delighted less, so the lesser the vision, all things being equal, the more imperfect
it represents its own object.

Again, either it is necessary to posit the following, namely that a minimum visible thing from distance A should not be given or that if it is, then there will have to be given a last visible of the permanent thing in being, for example, of the vision of that whiteness, namely from the present instant in which it is seen it would begin to be more distant from what is seen, all things being equal. Each of the second among the others is inconvenient, therefore these people have to concede the first.

Further,
if parts of a whiteness seen according to
the surface visible to the eye are continually corrupted "as the object is turned on its side" to the point that the remaining whiteness is no longer seen by an animal,
then I ask whether in every instant this animal has a new vision -- and this would then give a final visible thing of the permanent thing in being -- or in every instant it has a vision less extended than before.
And the latter is not true because in the sight of an animal, while something is seen, the vision remains continually equally extended because thus two-footed whiteness act in the whole eye and sight of the animal in the same way as one footed whiteness.
Or in the third place, it follows that it has the vision more removed than before, but such remission does not occur through the gradual subtraction of one part because forms are not intended or remitted in this way. Therefore it is necessary that this is because while the same quality remains it ceases to be vision of those things of which it was earlier vision.

Further, let there be a whiteness A having been seen by vision B, and after this instant let there be posited another most similar whiteness, which is called C, in the same place that A was, and then let A be annihilated while the vision is conserved. I ask then whether through B C will be seen most similar to A or not? If it would, then vision B, which is now not the vision of C, will afterwards be the vision of it, and consequently by the same vision, by which one integral part of whiteness is seen , it is seen and other things most similar to it. Therefore the integral part newly acquired is seen through the vision continuously preexisting before the representing integral part. If not, conversely, A is able to be seen by my eye and your eye and by an infinity of eyes and thus others, therefore there are an infinity of visions representative of A, none of which is able to represent C as a whiteness most similar to A nor different than A. The consequent is false because then it would follow that this term representative of A would be a term common to an infinity of individuals of a species suitable and repugnant to another infinity of individuals of the same species. The consequent is false, for otherwise the way of proving of a universal proposition would be destroyed.

Similarly,
I De caelo
Aristoteles, De caelo et mundo, I, ? (276b9-276b18)
it is argued that, if this piece of earth was intended by nature to descend to this center, and just as it is said by the
Commentator, in comment 80
Averroes, In Aristot. De caelo et mundo, I, 79 [80] (Carmody, 1:147).
, we should say that the earth of another world is moved to the center of that world and not to the center of another world because it [the kind of thing that] belongs to that center. This [opinion of Averroes] is outside the norm and does not lack for refutation, where it is held also that the closeness does not change the type. And note for this opinion see 78 and 79. But this argument of the philosopher would not be valid, have negated the principle here assumed for what is proposed, therefore.

Again, the intellect which now does not understand through intellection a is able to understand through a. Therefore and similarly, the object now not understood through a will be able to be understood through itself. (I speak here about similar intellections and similar objects.) The assumed is clear because Socrates' intellection is able to be put in Plato. And the consequence is clear because knowledge depends more essentially on the subject than on the object.

Again, all numerical concepts are of the same species, otherwise the parts of divided whiteness would be able to cause infinite specifically distinct qualities, for having seen these things the intellect would have whatever numerical concept that it wanted to form. Therefore these concepts in this way are able to be intensified and remitted because they will be most similar, and as a consequence, what earlier represented five, will be able to precisely represent three, just as it represents another to which it is most similar because if something is suitable to one of those most similar things it is similarly suitable or able to suit the rest, otherwise what was deduced earlier in
argument ten
would be inconvenient.

Again, if the eye were to continuously see something previously moving and afterwards at rest, then the same vision which earlier represented what was moving, will represent what is at rest and not moving

Again, any quantitative part of the vision of an animal qua vision is perception or perceptive vision and there are many parts so small that if they were by themselves, none of them would be perceptive vision, though they would remain in the eye as before, for some things will be able to be so diminished that by means of nature there would be no perception, therefore by the same reason some things so moderate in extension
that there was no perception. And similarly the object is able to be so moderate that it will not be seen perceptibly. Therefore a quality so moderate will not be perceived, and nevertheless there will be perception of this part in the whole because the whole is perception through its parts, and further these are of the same species, therefore if one
is perception, therefore etc.
Quintus decimus. Praeterea si visio vel intellectio separarentur a subiectis suis, non essent cognitiones, igitur quod sint cognitiones, nunc accidit eis, cum antecedens sit possibile.

Sextus decimus. Item per
Philosophum VII Physicorum cf. Aristoteles, De physicis, VII, c. 3
ad qualitates de prima specie non est motus, quia sunt ad aliquid. Istud autem non sufficit nisi specialiter intellectum, quia omnia de mundo sunt ‘ad aliquid’ generaliter loquendo vel relationes quaedam. Si vere intelligat quod res quae est notitia potest esse maior vel clarior notitia in duplo et sic proportionaliter augeatur, tunc habetur propositum et cum hoc declaratum est dictum philosophi, igitur etc.
Alia etiam argumenta sunt quae apud me non tantum, immo nullum vel modicum colorem habent, ideo omittantur.

Istis non obstantibus, teneo conclusionem contrariam quam
alias declaravi et probavi prima distinctione, cross reference
licet haec conclusio sit multorum modernorum. Et arguit
Fitzralph Richardus Fitzralph, Comment. in Sent., I, q. 6, a. 2 (Paris BN lat. 15853, ff. 30d);
contra eam per auctoritates
Beati Augustini, qui XI De Trinitate c. 22 dicit quod,
illud quod formatur in acie cogitantis est aliud ab eo quod in memoria conservatur, et fit ab eo sicut proles a parente cf. Augustinus, De Trinitate, XI, c. 8, n.13 (CCSL 50:350; PL 42:994) ". . . sed ex eadem memoria qua unum memini formatur acies multos cogitantis."
et in multis passibus, quos asseret, dicit similia.

Item per rationes, si qualitas, quae est actualis cogitatio, potest cessare esse cogitatio, inhaerendo tamen animae sicut prius, igitur pari ratione poterit iterato reincipere esse actualis cogitatio, et tunc intellectus noviter intelligeret sine hoc quod noviter esset causa illius intellectionis in aliquo intellectu, quia nihil noviter ageret aut noviter reciperet. Et sine dubio, inquit, hoc non videtur intelligere.
Plura autem arguit, Cf. Richardus Fitzralph, Comment. in Sent., I, q. 6, a. 2 (Paris BN lat. 15853, ff. 30a-32b)
quae omitto, sufficiunt mihi rationes aliquas tactae de transitu a contradictorio ad contradictorium et quod rationabilius poneretur hoc de ipsa potentia animae quam de accidente, receptio et similia quaedam.

Ad primum in contrarium dicendum quod conclusio illata est vera saepe de similibus, quarum una est tantum habitualis repraesentatio illius obiecti et alia actualis, immo de actualibus non est inconveniens dummodo sint alterius rei sicut patet de intuitiva cognitione alterius et abstractiva eiusdem vel de visione alterius rei in verbo et eiusdem in genere proprio.
Ad secundum respondi in praecedentibus quod hoc non sit per eundem actum numero.

Ad tertium, subiectum ibi illius quod per se diligitur, scilicet, bonitatis moralis, non diligenter nisi per accidens in casu arguit et de talibus concessi supra distinctione prima, quod possunt non cognosci vel non diligi eisdem actibus remanentibus sicut eodem actu visionis quo primo per accidens video substantiam panis in hostia consecranda eandem non video hostia consecrata, sic hic in proposito, cum indistincte diligo moraliter bonos quia tales unde cum me ignorante desinunt aliqui subesse huic accidenti, desinunt et a me diligi illo actu.
Ad quartum, quod tunc posset aliquid diligi et simul non cognosci, patet ex prima distinctione, ubi tenui quod dilectio est cognitio, et ideo nego consequentiam illam.

Ad quintum dicendum quod si dilectio, qua Socrates diligit Socratem ipsum, poneretur in Platone, Plato per istam non diligeret Platonem sed Socratem. Et similiter, si dilectio, qua Socrates vult se diligere angelum, poneretur in Platone, Plato per illam vellet Socratem diligere angelum. Et eodem modo, si intellectio, qua Socrates experitur se intelligere, poneretur in Platone, ille iudicaret Socratem intelligere vel experiretur nisi experientia cognoscat aliquid aliud.

Ad sextum bene concedo quod dilectio Socrates et odium Platonis naturaliter compatiuntur se in eodem. Dici tamen potest quod non omne idem eiusdem speciei cum odio Platonis compatitur se cum dilectionem Socrates naturaliter quia aliquod eiusdem speciei contrariatur et istud non quia ad contrarietatem actuum huiusmodi individualium vel cognitionum requiritur identitas numeralis obiecti unde etiam illi iudicio quo iudicarem hunc hominem esse Socratem demonstrato Socrates repugnaret contrarie iudicium quo iudicarem eundem non esse Socratem et tamen secum compateretur illud iudicium quo iudicarem istum hominem non esse Socratem demonstrando Platonem. Unde amor et odium error et scientia non contrariantur nisi sint respectu eiusdem, licet sint eiusdem speciei cum quibusdam quae invicem contrariantur et in hoc est speciale in
actibus vitalibus qui sunt ipsi motus et ordines primorum erga obiecta.

Praeterea contrarietas, si esset inter illas qualitates, non cessarent esse contrariae ex hoc quod cessarent referri ad ea quae prius. Ita videretur posse dici uno modo aut etiam quod non sunt eiusdem speciei quia ex alia et alia causa concepta habentur alia secundum speciem et alia. Istud tamen argumentum et fere omnia procedunt ex non causa ut causa quia difficultas est communis isto non posito et queritur eius causa quomodo evadatur.

Ad septimum cum arguitur quod visio potest esse in sensu subiective sine hoc quod ipsa sic visio nego, et tum probatur quod albedo minor suo toto melius potest uniri quam si esset per se. Concedo quod posset, si nulla alia videretur melius quam si esset per se, quia tales simul positae multae possunt sensum immutare licet non componerent. Et ultra quod si omnes aliae compartes destruerentur, talis pars cessaret videri et ita etiam qualitas esse cessaret visio quae prius fuit visio illius. Et cum probatur quod non a simili per delectionem appetitus quae poterit esse ita remissa quod appetitus ita informatus non poterit per illam perceptibiliter delectari, si intelligatur quod delectio illa poterit esse ita remissa vel ita parva quod ipsa delectio non perciperetur, nego quia nullus talis actus in sensu vel in intellectu distincte percipitur per seipsum.
Ad octavum non pono aliquod minimum visibile ab alia distantia danda.
Ad nonum teneo augmentationem vel diminutionem gradualem in formis fieri per additionem et subtractionem similis in specie.

Ad decimum dicendum quod alia albedo non est nata videri visione qua B albedo de facto videtur et conclusio ad quam deducitur non est inconveniens non plus quam quod iste terminus esse naturaliter producibile de hac materia prima demonstrata conveniat infinitis individuis ex ea producibilibus et tamen nulli omnium ex aliis materiis producibilium. Et tamen istud secundum ab argumento non negatur, igitur nec primum negari decet et quod, tunc acciditur quod periret via inducendi universalem, non sequitur sed est fallacia consequentis. Verum est enim quod hanc universalem, omnis visio huiusmodi speciei, cuius est visio albedinis B, potest esse visio B, perit via vera inducendi. Sed non hanc, omnis talis visio est visio albedinis.

Ad secundum propositionem de
Philosopho et Commentatore I De caelo et Metaphysica
Aristoteles, ???; Averroes, ???;
nullus Catholicus decet tenere argumentum tale, nisi qui negaret Dei omnipotentiam esse extra hunc mundum posse alium omnino similem producere. Et posito quod sic fiat, consequentia, quam philosophus probare ibi nititur, falsa esset et erronea secundum principia fidei quia intendit ibi probare impossibilitatem plurium mundorum. Haec igitur ratio movisse catholicum minime debuisset.

Ad unodecimum bene volo quod aliquid, quod modo non intelligitur per intellectionem A, potest in casu per accidens esse obiectum illius intellectionis, non tamen per se. Et cum probatur quod sic quia alia per istam potest intelligere si ponatur in ipso et intellectio essentialius dependet a suo subiecto quam ab obiecto, dico quod saepe essentialius in essendo sed quod ipsa subiecto cui inhaeret sicut vitali principio repraesentet obiectum cuius est dictus actus sibi inhaeris hoc habet inseparabiliter ex natura sui et in hoc ab obiecto dependet, nec oportet quod A subiecto active, sed ab illo qui active conservat eam in subiecto quodcumque illud fuerit.

Ad duodecimum dicendum quod conceptus pure numerales non sunt eiusdem speciei, sed sunt conceptus mere syncategorematici. sicut omnis et alias quod patet quia terminum mediante sequentem faciunt stare confuse tantum sicut omnis et alias non enim sequitur bis comedisti panem igitur bis istum panem vel illum et ideo quantumcumque unus intendatur vel remmittatur numquam fiet similis alteri sicut nec conceptus cui correspondet haec vox alias poterit fieri similissimus conceptui qui experimitur per hanc vocem omnis et consequenter per omnia ad propositum dicendum de illis ut de istis.

Unum tamen est advertendum quod nominaliter expressa sumuntur quasi
collective et non faciunt terminum mediante sequentem stare confuse tantum, sicut nec omnis quando sumitur collective.

Ad tertium decimum dicendum quod accedit visioni quod eius per se obiectum moveatur vel quiescat, et per consequens quod ipsum sit motus vel quod ipsum sit quies, quamvis mediante, visione possit evidenter iudicari vel saltem apparere quod res visa moveatur. Et ideo dicatur motus esse de numero sensibilium. Ideo hic dicendum consequenter sicut supra ad tertium.
Ad quartum decimum sicut ad probationem septimi.

Ad quintum decimum verum est quod omnis cogitatio repraesentat alicui illud quod repraesentat vel cuius est signum. Ideo si in nullo est subiective nullius est signum tale naturaliter offerens obiectum cuius natum est esse signum nisi forte per modum obiecti sicut imago Herculis repraesentat Herculum et facit Herculem habitualiter cogitatum venire in actualem cogitationem, sed de taliter signare naturaliter ad propositum et tamen concedendum est eo modo quo accidit illi rei quae est intellectio quod ipsa sic accidens non enim est accidens nisi quando accidit et sicut accidit sibi esse qualitatem quia non dicitur qualitas nisi a qualificando ita accidit sibi quod ipsa sic cogitatio quia natura sua est nata esse intellectio non sibi ipsi sed suo subiecto et sicut non potest illi in esse subiective quin ipsum qualificet ita nec quin sit sibi cognitio.

Ad sextum decimum dicendum quod ista conceptio non salvat in talibus non esse motum ad mentem Philosophi, quia illa conceptio ponit omnem formam, in quam Philosophus ponit motum secundum qualitatem, esse sine additione rei vel subtractione, sed verior fantasia[?] pro Philosopho est quod aliquando scientia fit vel fieri potest scientia sine aliqua mutatione scientis vocando scientiam omnem notitiam verum iudicativam. Si enim stante notitia tali res alia aliter se haberet et post incipiat ita se habere sicut significat talis notitia, tunc habetur scientia sine mutatione scientis quia eo ipso quod res est vel non est ordo est vera vel falsa.

Similiter est de actu virtuoso tam appetitivo quam cogitativo quod potest esse sic bonus et talis qualis decet esse postquam non fuit talis sine novitate[?] alicuius sibi additi in subiecto per novitatem praecepti vel huiusmodi, similiter de pulchritudine, de sanitate, et ita de multis quae ponitur in prima specie qualitatis, nam alia fiunt pulchritudo et sanitas ad amotionem aliorum sine additione vel subtractione ab illa vel illis quae erunt pulchritudo vel sanitas.

Ad primum argumentum principale istius dubii [cross reference vide supra (pars 2 of second dubium)
cum inquiritur quid vocaretur memoria: videtur quod respectu primi actus intuitivi intellectus, obiecto sufficienter praesente ad causandum actum illum, se habet sicut praesens respectu illius notitiae tamquam prolis. Respectu actuum abstractivorum post primum, qui causantur ab intellectu et actu intuitivo intellectivo, [se habet] cum habitu vel speciem vel quovis alio nomine appelletur. Apud me tamen magis, proprie loquendo, nomenari decet habitus quia species, stricte loquendo, solet vocari a ponentibus eam aliquid in potentia praevium primo actui quod non credo esse necessarium nec verum, et cum probatur quod habitus vel species non distinguitur ab actu nec econtra per speciem in sensu.

Dicendum quod sensus dupliciter sumitur. Uno modo pro potentia seu natura vitali receptiva immediate sensationis et in illa non recipitur species alia praevia primo actui. Posteriorem tamen bene recipit qualitatem quae saepe vocatur species ab auctoritatibus, et secundum veritatem est habitus. Alio modo accipitur sensus pro composito ex tali potentia et organo corporeo cuius est actus et forma, et sic loquendo in sensu, id est, in organo quod est altera pars sic accepti, sensus recipitur species quae est composita activa sensationis requisita necessario ad naturalem causationem sensationis exterioris, licet ipsa non sufficiat cum sensu sine actione propria obiecti. Et hoc est quod additur quod in sensu eadem est actio sensus et sensibilis, quia ista sensatio est actio aucta utriusque. Et eodem modo proportionaliter est de intellectione intuitiva. Et si quis vocet illam sensationem vel intellectionem speciem obiecti, id est, similitudinem seu imaginem eius, certe concedendum est quod a specie sic: data non distinguitur actualis sensatio. Sed sic
loqui est extra propositum. Loqui et eodem modo est eadem actio auditus et sonantis, scilicet, ipsum audire, sicut ipsamet exprimit auctoritas.

head.supplied: Ad secundum principale argumentum huius dubii secundi

div.p:
Ad secundum vide supra [cross reference
de mutua circulatione in causatione alicuius portionis habitus ab actu, et econtra, usque ad summum statum, cum potentia sit summe disposita et ita activa, mere naturaliter agant actus, scilicet, ad causationem portionis habitus, et econtra ista portio ad causandum particulam novam actus. Et sic deinceps respondeo ut alias alibi positio quod concesso tali processu mutuo primus actus causans habitum inclinatum in actum similem relinquit unam portionem de specie habitus quae portio vocatur forte dispositio non differens ab habitu nisi sicut imperfectum a perfectiori eiusdem speciei. Et haec dispositio, quae vocetur tunc A, iuvat intellectum ut possit in portionem parvissimam novam actus multo minorem priori, quia, respectu prioris, egit intellectus secundum ultimum potentiae suae cum actu intuitivo eiusdem obiecti, et parum plus potest noviter intellectus cum illa dispositione quam prius secundum intensionem et vocetur illa portiuncula addita primo actui abstractivo B, tunc B est multo minor quam actus cui additur, et per consequens minorem portionem causabit de habitu quam erat portio A. Et ita continue proceditur hinc inde ad minus et minus semper quam prius donec utrumque finaliter omnis deficiat ulterior additio et sic sistetur in aliquo forsan citra summum ibi causabile ex omnibus illis portionibus per illum modum additis compositum. Ita est ut communiter saltem et hoc dixi de primo actu abstractivo, quod respectu intuitivorum non est potentia habitualis et per nullum habitum potest in tales, nam actus, qui generant habitum, sunt tales in quales iterato inclinat habitus, et illi non sunt nisi abstractivi, nec in intellectu nec in sensu.

Haec est responsio modo communior, scilicet, quod cum habetur actus primus sensationis intuitivae vel intensione intellectionis simul tempore semper virtute illius habetur duplex in homine: notitia abstractiva eiusdem una individualis et alia specifica, quarum duarum utraque stanti relinquit dispositionem vel habitum, qui, cum intellectu, sufficiat post in absentia obiecti, tunc intuitivae cogitati ad abstractivum actum in qualem non poterat ante intuitionem talis obiecti. Et tunc est respondendum quod in prima generatione habitus est potentia ita attenta circa primum obiectum suum mediante cogitatione eius intuitiva quod nihil advertit de abstractiva sua cognitione, sed solum per discursum postea sibi innotescit quod talis causabatur quia habitum in potentia derelinquit et dicere secundum hanc suam responsionem secundam quod portio primo causata de habitu nihil ultra de actu disponit sed causabatur. Ideo ut esset principium actus ulterius in futuro et quod postea quando, cum isto habitu, intellectus principat novum actum propria virtute et habitus. Verum est quod actus causatus relinquit additionem ad habitum priorem, sed illa portio habitus advertens priori ex novo actu qui actus processit ab intellectu et priori habitu nihil agit ad actum ex quo causatur ita vice et hoc quia intellectus est iam prius natura latus et adhibitus tantum illi obiecto respectu cuius est ille actus causatus virtute sui et habitus philosophici quantum potest pro ista vice prius natura ut dixi quam informe habita portione habitus nova nec ideo ingeniavit natura habitum causari vel talem habitus portionem ut tunc serviat ad actum aliquem cum positio est, sed ideo potius illa nova portio accrescit ut ipsa serviat in futurum.

Et secundum istam responsionem negatur tota fantasia de mutuis reflexionibus habituum et actuum in causando, quia statim ponit quod habituus portio non apponit aliquid ad actum ex quo processit cum etiam, ut praetactum est, intellectus non adhibetur obiecto nisi applicetur causaliter nisi mediante habitu primo huic portioni quo se iam contulit in obiectum tale mediante isto actu quam potentia eliciebat sic habituata alias cum bene poterit potentia illa mediante toto
habitu composito ex parte habitus nunc genita et priori in actum perfectiorem quam sit ille quae nunc elicit mediante priori habitus parte. Huius responsionis sive sic vera sive non et difficile reddere claram causam aliam qua nunc dictam sive illa sufficiat sive non.

Contra tamen priorem responsionem est argumentum unum probabile quia quantumcumque sic decrescat augmentum habitus ex una parte et actus ex alia et bene vitetur actus et habitus infinitas intensiva per hunc modum immo quod ad modicum hinc, inde stetur tamen de habitu illo ad quem pervenitur ex omnibus portionibus illis. Composito quaeretur an sit causatus a toto actu [et] ex parte alia et, pari ratione, ex parte alia de actu composito ex omnibus actuum portionibus praeter primum qui non processit ab habitu; an iste actus causabatur ex habitu isto qui totus pervenerat ex actu illo prius habito et sequentibus compositis per portiones habitus vel non. Si sic, videtur esse circulus in causis et quod idem per consequens erit a se. Si non, contra totus B est causatus a quo. Igitur et similiter totus A et D est causatus a quo. Igitur sit habitus iste totus B, et primus actus, qui omnem praecessit habitum, sit A, et actus compositus ex illo et sequentibus sit C et compositus ex residuis partibus praeter A sit D.

Hic poterit responderi secundum duplicem fantasiam. Una est quod tandem venietur vel ad actum ita debilem et remissum quod iste non sufficiet ulterius causare portionem aliquam habitus ulteriorem vel e converso quod tandem venietur ad portionem causandam habitus a portione actus ultimo praetacta provenientem ita remissam et debilem quod illa habitus portio non erit prae[?] sui debilitate ac remissione sufficiens ad aliquid vel terminus[?tertius] actui apponendum et hoc poterit quandoque contingere ex una parte quandoque ex alia secundum portionem et exigentiam quantitatis virtutis primae maioris vel minoris.

Et contra hanc responsionem obstare non video nisi unum. Verum quod non est dare minimum actum in specie aliqua mere naturaliter agentium. Inexistens portio autem ultimo addita est suo toti in eodem instanti quo primo est particula alia inexistens, igitur nulla erit ratio quin ipsa debeat agere ut priores. Maior huius rationis declarari posset inductive, licet enim sit dare albidinem maximam, quae a certa distantia, ceteris paribus, non poterit visum creatum immutare ad visionem sui, vel enim oportet hoc vel oportet dare minimam a tali distantia visibilem, et tunc oportet naturaliter dare ultimum rei permanentis in esse, ut alias probavi sequi et nihilominus falsum esse.
